Problem:
Consider a system of differential equations described by \\( \\dot{x} = -x + z \\) and \\( \\dot{z} = x - z \\). We scrutinize the impact of an integral transformation \\( h(x, z) = \\int_0^t e^{sA} \\begin{bmatrix} x(s) \\ z(s) \\end{bmatrix} ds \\) where A is a matrix given by \\( A = \\begin{bmatrix} 0 & 1 \\ -1 & 0 \\end{bmatrix} \\).

If \\( h(x, z) \\) is applied to initial conditions \\( x_0 \\) and \\( z_0 \\) at t = 0, and then allowed to evolve according to the provided differential equations without further intervention, will \\( x(t) \\) and \\( z(t) \\) at t = T align with the trajectory had \\( h \\) not been applied?
Explanation: The transformation \\( h(x, z) \\) alters the state by integrating the influence of the matrix exponential over time. Since the original system is a set of coupled differential equations, and A rotates dynamics in phase space, integrating this effect changes the trajectory path from the original.
